content: Good morning everyone

Hello everyone,

It's the for the governance meeting! React/Reply with :wave: to indicate your attendance. Todays agenda can found in the hackmd, and I've also pasted it below.

  • Project Group RFC
  • Pre-RFC RFC
  • Domain WG Retrospective
cc @WG-governance
@Val Grimm is on her way
Cool, while we wait I'll start with a status update on the project group rfc.
The RFC is now in FCP, so it should be merged by the next meeting. https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2856
That's all.
If no one has anything else to mention on that topic I think we can move on to @Nell Shamrell-Harrington and the Pre-RFC RFC.
I do not have any updates on that today
(got pulled into other things over the past two weeks)
That's fine, that leaves the domain WG retrospective.
Niko got some feedback from the WGs that was in this document. https://hackmd.io/xsjzAW5-ThulwN9FlaP9NA

nikomatsakis said:

We discussed it very briefly in the core team meeting, I think the logic next step is probably trying to write-up the notes from before, and maybe have a conversation about what people are really looking for when they think about forming a domain WG
which notes from before,
@Val Grimm The hackmd I linked above.
qh ok
I guess, is anyone interested on working on turning this into a post?
ah ok
sure
I thought we were supposed to discuss here first
its sort of spaghetti and inconclusive but I can do something
something
sorry on an azerty and out of practice
Yeah, I'm not actually sure that the notes are "actionable" as such.
ditto
There was an intersting conversation last time about the idea of what domain working groups are for
Right - I think we need to have one or more fairly concrete ideas about that before writing a blog post
if they start as project groups
or going public in any other way
yes
or if they are scouting parties to see what is relevant like embedded?

I think some of the comments there that I find most insightful/helpful are:

the working group isn’t really an effective place to push [wasm] forward anymore

bureaucratic overhead associated with WG
@BatmanAoD (Kyle Strand) To be clear those two comments are from two different groups.

I guess my current "take" is: domain-specific Rust efforts benefit from having some organizational structure, but there doesn't seem to be much benefit in having that structure be a part of the overall Rust project structure
Yeah, sorry, I completely decontextualized them
so how is a connection maintained, things kept coherent?
or is that a core tenet?
I'm not sure it is. At least, I don't see why it needs to be.
The game dev one has an interesting point: paying for domain names
That's something Rust could in theory support, if it had formal funding for such things
But since it doesn't yet, it's not clear that's an immediate advantage (of connecting domain groups to the Rust project) for anybody
thing is, are there benefits in cross pollination between embedded and other domains and core lang?
Does the language evolve from their input?
I would say yes.

Looks like WASM at least came up with some things that could be adopted by the Rust project:

Have to decide how to distribute the repos

some of them could move to rust-lang
notably wasm-bindgen, wasm-pack, and the Rust + WASM book
so if the language evolves from their input
I also think there are few action items from the notes.

How to manage optics? Will this be read as “divestment”?
fitzgen writes: “I think Wasm is still a big opportunity for Rust, both on the Web and elsewhere with WASI, it’s just that the working group isn’t really an effective place to push that forward anymore. So how do we gracefully end this particular working group without making it look like “Rust gives up on Wasm” or something like that?”

An idea I had when we last discussed this was that domain groups could act as sources for "spinning up" project-groups, where a project group is a focused effort to investigate/develop one or more RFCs for Rust.
so it seems like there are at least two concerns here
I think how do we handle announcing that a group is spinning down without coming across as putting a value on the technology is an interesting challenge.
@XAMPPRocky I think that particular action item can only be resolved by the broader discussion about how domain work should relate to the Rust project in general.
Is that not the topic though?
It is! That's what I mean. I don't see the spinning-down announcement as an immediately-actionable thing.
yes. although re WASM it seems like the big picture decisions shouldnt be determined by the decision about the involvement of a handful of people with the specific WASM project
which imo needs its own response
thing is
I think that "how do we 'spin' this" will fall naturally out of a satisfying answer to "how does Rust support domain work".
So, does it matter to articulate why domain groups exist and their lifecycle, as for projects?
and then of course there's the buyin phase, but it could send a message about the value of domain work in the vision of Rust?
and also looking at embedded, a sync mechanism
I believe we discussed some of the original motivations here for context. https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/223182-wg-governance/topic/Meeting.202020-03-26/near/191920670
(mistyped here, disregqrd)

Val Grimm said:

So, does it matter to articulate why domain groups exist and their lifecycle, as for projects?

I don't have a definite answer to this, but my inclination is - no: domain groups should have their own organizational structure, lifecycle, etc.
ok, so the reason we'rfe discussing this is that there is an issue. looking at the notes it seems to be a comm disconnect between domain and core?
going particularly on embedded
what concrete problems are wze trying to solve?
what will look different after we solve this?

Well I think we should maybe be a bit tighter than that. I think we should have some kind of "recommended" structure and life-cycle. To give people a structure and foundation to build off. I feel like some problems arise from everything being bespoke. Of course if someone wants to work differently that's not a problem, but I feel that most people want some kind framework to work in.
Yes!
it's always good to at least have a sample structure people can work from
Recommend-but-not-require seems a good model
if they wish to do something different, they are welcome to, but this means they have a place to start
so a domain wg rfc then

My (limited) perception is that the proximate, visible issue is that domain groups have some "official" status, but kind of seem to be "languishing", and it's unclear to all involved (?) how exactly they relate to the core Rust teams.
well, whats a concrete example of a domain groups work evolving core Rust?
this can be a jumping off point to think about this
or the relationship could manifest in other ways
how it looks when it is working vs languishing
or would look
having examples to refer to would be quite helpful
Well it's hard to link to but I believe the entire WASM/emscripten compiler targets came as a result of the domain WG work.
ok, and what was the mechanism by which they came in?
that would be a great example to include in the RFC

Val Grimm said:

ok, and what was the mechanism by which they came in?

Pull requests as those changes don't require RFCs.
I'm not actually sure who was involved in any of these efforts, except for Nick & Alex being mentioned in the "WASM" section of those hackmd notes
so were the people working on the WASM/emscripten targets all also core folks at that time?
or were some of them only active in the domain group?
There was definitely more people involved.
As a quick time check we have ~20 minutes left, does anyone have anything else that they would like to bring up before we continue?
I have one thing but it can be discussed next time
@Val Grimm well now I'm curious :)
On the dev-platform-request list on March 22 there was a question about the accuracy of this list of Rust components in Firefox. https://wiki.mozilla.org/Oxidation#Rust_Components.
We also have the question from the other day about re-opening the turbfish discussion in a "careful" way
yes!
(scare quotes b/c we don't know what that would entail yet, not b/c we won't actually be careful)
on turbofish - I feel like opening a new RFC with the summary of the discussion from the previous one would be a good place to start
That seems like a step in the right direction, but I don't see how it would prevent the thread from devolving again pretty quickly...
Okay, well let's try to get the action items for the domain WG retrospective. One is to follow up with the "Secure Code WG" as they are the only group with missing feedback.
I mean, I didn't even participate in the original discussion and I have the impulse to go in and argue about it!
@BatmanAoD (Kyle Strand) it's worth trying
unless someone has a different idea

I can follow up on those action items @XAMPPRocky although Ill need some help likely. thing is, I need to understand what the purpose of the feedback is, just to see how the domain wgs feel about being domain wgs?
To be honest I think we should maybe try to reach out to any or all the groups again. Enough time has past and enough has happened that maybe there is probably more to reflect on.
I feel like we need to first have a clear sense of what we are trying to accomplish
It sounds like another action item is "gather some concrete examples of domain groups directly interacting w/ the Rust project, e.g. by submitting PRs to Rust"
@Val Grimm Sure, we can think through what those questions should be.
I'm going to start a draft one sec
Maybe a good question to pose to them would be "what would you miss if you were 'cut off' from the project and became a community group"
So, the purpose of a domain group could be to bring insights back to core?
https://hackmd.io/@XAMPPRocky/SylHELkYL
because it shouldn tjust be about what the domain group individuams want but about the big picture, why there are domain wgs
what purpose they can serve
(willbe slow getting into hqckmd as my laptop dying means resetting all passwords atm as no pwd mgr again yet)

I mentioned in the previous discussion that one benefit is visibility to outsiders; domain groups implicitly answer these questions:

  • In which domains does Rust have a vested interest in building up the ecosystem and generally "succeeding" via adoption?
  • If I wanted to do some work in a domain using Rust, is there an existing community I can go to for support? If I wanted to propose changes to Rust to aid with this work, is there an existing channel?
sounds good

Okay, we have ten minutes left. For the agenda of the next meeting, I'd like to continue the work on domain WGs and @Nell Shamrell-Harrington would you want to have an update on the Pre-RFC RFC or should we defer it?
let's defer

Okay, the three questions we have so far is

  • What are some notable changes that your group has made to Rust?
    • How do you feel about the process it took to get those changes accepted?
  • How do you feel your group benefits from being part of the Rust organisation?
I think those are probably sufficient. They're clear and they get at the core of the issue.
Plus we probably don't want to send people a survey that will take up too much time!
Id want to add one more
not sure how to phrase
want ask for their experience if any of how other languages integrate cross-domain work in the core language
there was an example about C in that regard recently . . .
something backwards compatibility something. send after the meeting, were almost out of time.
and my C example is not perfect, but this problem isnt unique to Rust
Okay, that's our time. Thanks everyone! :wave:
thank you!
:wave:

@Val Grimm Does this fit the spirit of your question?

  • If relevant, how has your experience with Rust's Working Group's compared to working in other language domain groups?
